question: How is wind considered in the take-off performance data of the Aeroplane Operations Manuals?

choices.choice: Unfactored headwind and tailwind components are used.
Not more than 80% headwind and not less than 125% tailwind.
Since take-offs with tailwind are not permitted, only headwinds are considered
Not more than 50% of a headwind and not less than 150% of the tailwind.

subject: Performance

question: What will be the influence on the aeroplane performance if aerodrome pressure altitude is increased?

choices.choice: It will increase the take-off distance.
It will decrease the take-off distance.
It will increase the take-off distance available.
It will increase the accelerate stop distance available.

subject: Performance

question: The required Take-off Distance (TOD) and the field length limited Take-off Mass (TOM) are different for the zero flap case and take-off position flap case. What is the result of flap setting in take-off position compared to zero flap position?

choices.choice: Increased TOD required and decreased field length limited TOM.
Increased TOD required and increased field length limited TOM.
Decreased TOD required and decreased field length limited TOM.
Decreased TOD required and increased field length limited TOM.

subject: Performance

question: The take-off distance available is:

choices.choice: the total runway length, without clearway even if this one exists.
the length of the take-off run available plus the length of the clearway available.
the runway length minus stopway.
the runway length plus half of the clearway.

subject: Performance

question: During take-off, the thrust of a fixed pitch propeller:

choices.choice: increases slightly while the aeroplane speed builds up
varies with mass changes only.
has no change during take-off and climb.
decreases while the aeroplane speed builds up.

subject: Performance

question: What will be the effect on an aeroplane’s performance if aerodrome pressure altitude is decreased?

choices.choice: It will increase the take-off distance required
It will increase the take-off ground run.
It will decrease the take-off distance required.
It will increase the accelerate stop distance.

subject: Performance

question: The take-off distance of an aircraft is 800m in a standard atmosphere with no wind and at 0 ft pressure altitude. Using the following corrections: ± 20 m / 1 000 ft field elevation – 5 m / kt headwind + 10 m / kt tail wind ± 15 m / % runway slope ± 5 m / °C deviation from standard temperature The take-off distance from an airport at 2 000 ft elevation, temperature 21°C, QNH 1013.25 hPa, 2% up-slope, 5 kt tail wind is:
subject: Performance

question: An uphill slope:

choices.choice: increases the take-off distance more than the accelerate stop distance.
decreases the accelerate stop distance only.
decreases the take-off distance only.
increases the allowed take-off mass.

subject: Performance

question: Other factors remaining constant and not limiting, how does increasing pressure altitude affect allowable takeoff mass?

choices.choice: Allowable take-off mass remains uninfluenced up to 5000 ft pressure altitude.
Allowable take-off mass decreases.
Allowable take-off mass increases.
There is no effect on allowable take-off mass

subject: Performance

question: In reality, the net thrust of a jet engine at constant RPM:

choices.choice: does not change with changing altitude.
is independent of the airspeed.
decreases with the airspeed.
increases with the airspeed.

subject: Performance

question: Which of the following are to be taken into account for the runway in use for take-off?

choices.choice: Airport elevation, runway slope, standard temperature, pressure altitude and wind components.
Airport elevation, runway slope, outside air temperature, standard pressure and wind components.
Airport elevation, runway slope, outside air temperature, pressure altitude and wind components.
Airport elevation, runway slope, standard temperature, standard pressure and wind components.

subject: Performance

question: For a take-off in slush, the slush drag:

choices.choice: Will increase up to aquaplane speed and then remain constant
Will increase up to aquaplane speed and then decrease
Will increase up to aquaplane speed and then increase at a greater rate.
Will decrease progressively up to the lift off speed.

subject: Performance

question: With contamination on the aircraft wings and fuselage only:

choices.choice: The TODR will be unaffected.
The ASDR will decrease.
Stalling speed is not affected
The lift off speed will be increased.

subject: Performance

question: The gross take-off distance (TOD) is defined as being from brake release until:

choices.choice: The aeroplane's main wheel lifts off the runway.
The aeroplane has reached 35 ft.
The aeroplane has reached the screen height.
The aeroplane is safely off the ground.

subject: Performance

question: The result of a higher flap setting up to the optimum at take-off is:

choices.choice: a higher VR.
a longer take-off run.
a shorter ground roll.
an increased acceleration.

subject: Performance

question: VR is the speed at which:

choices.choice: The aeroplane nose wheel is off the ground.
The pilot initiate the action required to raise the nose wheel off the ground.
The main wheels lift off the ground
The aeroplane rotates about the longitudinal axis.

subject: Performance

question: During take-off:

choices.choice: The acceleration force decreases.
Wheel drag increases.
Thrust increases
Total drag decreases

subject: Performance

question: High altitudes, hot air and humid conditions will:

choices.choice: Increase the take-off payload.
Decrease the take-off mass.
Increase the take-off performance
Decrease the take-off distance.

subject: Performance

question: The main purpose for taking off into wind is to:

choices.choice: Decrease the true ground speed.
Decrease the aeroplane performance.
Increase the true ground speed.
Increase the take-off distance.

subject: Performance

question: What is the effect of a contaminated runway on the take-off?

choices.choice: Increases the take-off distance and greatly increases the accelerate stop distance.
Increases the take-off distance and decreases the accelerate stop distance.
Decreases the take-off distance and increases the accelerate stop distance.
Decreases the take-off distance and greatly decreases the accelerate stop distance.

subject: Performance

question: Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.choice: If a clearway or a stopway is used, the lift-off point must be attainable at least by the end of the permanent runway surface.
A stopway means an area beyond the take-off run available, able to support the aeroplane during an aborted take-off.
An under-run is an area beyond the runway end which can be used for an aborted take-off.
A clearway is an area beyond the runway which can be used for an aborted take-off.

subject: Performance

question: A ‘Balanced Field Length’ is said to exist where:

choices.choice: The accelerate stop distance available is equal to the take-off distance available.
The clearway does not equal the stopway.
The accelerate stop distance is equal to the all engine take-off distance.
The one engine out take-off distance is equal to the all engine take-off distance.

subject: Performance

question: The stopway is an area which allows an increase only in:

choices.choice: the accelerate - stop distance available
the take-off run available.
the take-off distance available.
the landing distance available.

subject: Performance

question: An airport has a 3000 metres long runway, and a 2000 meter clearway at each end of that runway. For the calculation of the maximum allowed take-off mass, the take-off distance available cannot be greater than:

choices.choice: 4000 metres
3000 metres
5000 metres
4500 metres

subject: Performance

question: Can the length of a stopway be added to the runway length to determine the take-off distance available?

choices.choice: Yes, but the stopway must be able to carry the weight of the aeroplane.
Yes, but the stopway must have the same width as the runway.
No
No, unless its centreline is on the extended centreline of the runway.

subject: Performance

question: In relation to runway strength, the ACN:

choices.choice: Must not exceed 90% of the PCN and then only if special procedures are followed
May exceed the PCN by up to 10% or 50 % if special procedures are followed
May exceed the PCN by a factor of 2
Must equal the PCN

subject: Performance

question: The TODA is:

choices.choice: Declared runway length only.
Declared runway length plus clearway.
Declared runway length plus stopway.
Declared runway length plus clearway and stopway.

subject: Performance

question: Take-off distance available is?

choices.choice: Take-off run available plus clearway
Take-off run minus the clearway, even if clearway exists
Always 1.5 times the TORA.
50% of the TORA.

subject: Performance

question: Can a clearway be used in the accelerate stop distance calculations?

choices.choice: Yes
No
Only if the clearway is shorter than the stopway
Only if there is no clearway.

subject: Performance

question: The take-off distance available is?

choices.choice: The total runway length, without clearway even if this one exists.
The length of the take-off run available plus any length of clearway available, up to a maximum of 50% of TORA.
The runway length minus stopway.
The runway length plus of the clearway.

subject: Performance

question: The stopway is:

choices.choice: at least as wide as the runway.
no less than 152 wide.
no less than 500 ft wide.
as strong as the main runway.

subject: Performance

question: Which class of aeroplane describes all multi-engine turbo-jet aeroplanes?

choices.choice: Unclassified.
Class C.
Class B.
Class A.

subject: Performance

question: A propeller aeroplane with nine or less passenger seats and with a maximum take-off mass of 5700 kg or less is described as:

choices.choice: Unclassified.
Class C.
Class B.
Class A.

subject: Performance

question: What happens to the drag of a jet aeroplane if, during the initial climb after takeoff, a constant IAS and constant configuration is maintained? (Assume a constant mass..

choices.choice: The drag decreases
The drag increases initially and decrease thereafter
The drag remains almost constant
The drag increases considerably

subject: Performance

question: The speed for best rate of climb is called?

choices.choice: VO
VY
VX
V2

subject: Performance

question: An increase in atmospheric pressure has, among other things, the following consequences on take-off performance

choices.choice: a reduced take-off distance and degraded initial climb performance
a reduced take-off distance and improved initial climb performance
an increases take-off distance and degraded initial climb performance
an increased take-off distance and improved initial climb performance

subject: Performance

question: A higher outside air temperature

choices.choice: does not have any noticeable effect on climb performance
reduces the angle of climb but increases the rate of climb
reduces the angle and the rate of climb
increases the angle of climb but decreases the rate of climb

subject: Performance

question: In un-accelerated climb:

choices.choice: thrust equals drag plus the uphill component of the gross weight in the flight path direction
thrust equals drag plus the downhill component of the gross weight in the flight path direction
lift is greater than the gross weight
lift equals weight plus the vertical component of the drag

subject: Performance

question: A jet aeroplane is climbing at a constant IAS with maximum climb thrust. How will the climb angle / the pitch angle change?

choices.choice: Remain constant / decrease
Remain constant / become larger
Reduce / decrease
Reduce / remain constant

subject: Performance

question: Take-off performance data, for the ambient conditions, show the following limitations with flap 10° selected: Runway or Field limit mass: 5,270 kg Obstacle limit mass: 4,630 kg If the esmated take-off mass 5,000 kg it would be prudent to consider a take-off with flaps at:

choices.choice: 20°, both limitations are increased
5°, the obstacle limit mass is increased but the runway limit mass decreases
5°, both limitations are increased
20°, the obstacle limit mass is increased but the runway limit mass decreases.

subject: Performance

question: A four jet-engined aeroplane whose mass is 150 000 kg is established on climb with engines operating. The lift over drag ratio is 14:1. Each engine has a thrust of 75 000 Newtons. The gradient of climb is : (given: g=10m/s².
subject: Performance

question: How does the best angle of climb and best rate of climb vary with increasing altitude?

choices.choice: Both decrease
Both increase
Best angle of climb increases while best rate of climb decreases
Best angle of climb decreases while best rate of climb increases

subject: Performance

question: Following a take-off determined by the 50ft (15m) screen height, a light twin climbs on a 10% ground gradient. It will clear a 900 m high obstacle situated at 10,000 m from the 50ft clearing point with an obstacle clearance of:

choices.choice: It will not clear the obstacle

subject: Performance

question: The rate of climb:

choices.choice: is approximately the climb gradient multiplied by the true airspeed divided by 100.
is the downhill component of the true airspeed
is angle of climb multiplied by the true airspeed
is the horizontal component of the true airspeed

subject: Performance

question: Assuming that the required lift exists, which forces determine an aeroplane’s angle of climb?

choices.choice: Thrust and drag only
Weight and thrust only
Weight, drag and thrust
Weight and drag only

subject: Performance

question: which of the following provides maximum obstacle clearance during climb?

choices.choice: The speed for maximum rate of climb
The speed, at which the flaps may be selected one position further UP.
The speed for maximum climb angle Vx.

subject: Performance

question: Which speed provides maximum obstacle clearance during climb?

choices.choice: The speed for which the ratio between rate of climb and forward speed is maximum.
The speed for maximum rate of climb
V2

subject: Performance

question: Which of the equations below expresses approximately the unaccelerated percentage climb gradient for small climb angles?

choices.choice: Climb Gradient = (Thrust - Drag / Weight x 100
Climb Gradient = (Thrust + Drag / Lift x 100
Climb Gradient = (Thrust + Mass / Lift x 100
Climb Gradient = (Lift / Weight x 100

subject: Performance

question: The absolute ceiling:

choices.choice: is the altitude at which the best climb gradient attainable is 5%
is the altitude at which the aeroplane reaches a maximum rate of climb of 100 ft/min
is the altitude at which the rate of climb is theoretically zero
can be reached only with minimum steady flight speed

subject: Performance

question: The climb gradient of an aircraft after take-off is 6% in standard atmosphere, no wind, at 0 ft pressure altitude. Using the following corrections: ± 0.2 % / 1 000 ft field elevation, ± 0.1 % / °C from standard temperature, -1 % with wing anti-ice, – 0.5 % with engine anti-ice. The climb gradient after take-off from an airport situated at 1 000 ft, 17°C; QNH 1013.25 hPa, with wing and engine anti-ice operating for a functional check is:
subject: Performance

question: As long as an aeroplane is in a positive climb:

choices.choice: VX is always below VY
VX is sometimes below and sometimes above VY depending on altitude
VX is always above VY
VY is always above VMO

subject: Performance

question: A constant headwind component:

choices.choice: increases the angle of flight path during climb.
increases the best rate of climb
decreases the angle of climb
increases the maximum endurance

subject: Performance

question: A higher gross mass at the same altitude will cause:

choices.choice: VY and VX to decrease.
VX to increase and VY to decrease
VY and VX to remain constant since they are not affected by a higher gross mass
VY and VX to increase

subject: Performance

question: With an true airspeed of 194 kt and a vertical speed of 1,000 ft/min, the climb gradient is approximately:
subject: Performance

question: With take-off flaps set, Vx and Vy will be:

choices.choice: lower than that for clean configuration
higher than that for clean configuration
same as that for clean configuration
changed so that Vx increases and Vy decreases compared to clean configuration

subject: Performance

question: The maximum rate of climb that can be maintained at the absolute ceiling is:

choices.choice: 0 ft/min
125 ft/min
500 ft/min
100 ft/min

subject: Performance

question: A head wind will:

choices.choice: increase the rate of climb
shorten the time of climb
increase the climb flight path angle
increase the angle of climb

subject: Performance

question: VX is:

choices.choice: the speed for best rate of climb
the speed for best specific range
the speed for best angle of flight path
the speed for best angle of climb

subject: Performance

question: The best rate of climb at a constant gross mass:

choices.choice: decreases with increasing altitude since the thrust available decreases due to the lower air density
increases with increasing altitude since the drag decreases due to the lower air density
increases with increasing altitude due to the higher true airspeed
is independent of altitude

subject: Performance

question: During a climb with all engines operating, the altitude where the rate of climb reduces to 100 ft/min is called:

choices.choice: Thrust ceiling
Maximum transfer ceiling
Service ceiling
Absolute ceiling

subject: Performance

question: With all other factors remaining constant, how does increasing altitude affect Vx and Vy as a TAS:

choices.choice: Vx will decrease and Vy will increase
Both will increase
Both will remain the same
Both will decrease

subject: Performance

question: Any acceleration in climb, with a constant power setting:

choices.choice: improves the climb gradient if the airspeed is below VX
improves the rate of climb if the airspeed is below VY
decreases rate of climb and increases angle of climb
decreases the rate of climb and the angle of climb

subject: Performance

question: For an aircraft maintaining 100kt true airspeed and a climb gradient of 3.3% with no wind, what would be the approximate rate of climb?

choices.choice: 330 ft/min
3,300 ft/min

subject: Performance

question: With a jet aeroplane, the maximum climb angle can be flown at approximately:

choices.choice: 1.2 Vs
1.1 Vs
The highest L/C ratio
The highest L/D² ratio

subject: Performance

question: During a climb to the cruising level, any headwind component:

choices.choice: decrease the climb time
decreases the ground distance flown during that climb
increases the amount of fuel for the climb
increases the climb time

subject: Performance

question: The pilot of a single engine aircraft has established the climb performance. The carriage of an additional passenger will cause the climb performance to be:

choices.choice: Degraded
Improved
Unchanged
Unchanged, if a short field take-off is adopted

subject: Performance

question: A headwind component increasing with altitude, as compared to zero wind condition: (assuming IAS is constant.

choices.choice: Improves angle and rate of climb
decreases angle and rate of climb
has no effect on rate of climb
does not have any effect on the angle of flight path during climb

subject: Performance

question: Which of the following combinations adversely affects take-off and initial climb performance?

choices.choice: High temperature and low relative humidity
Low temperature and low relative humidity
High temperature and high relative humidity
Low temperature and high relative humidity

subject: Performance

question: A decrease in atmosphereic pressure has, among other things, the following consequences on take-off performance:

choices.choice: a reduced take-off distance and degraded initial climb performance
an increased take-off distance and degraded initial climb performance
a reduced take-off distance and improved initial climb performance
an increased take-off distance and improved initial climb performance

subject: Performance

question: The angle of climb with flaps extended, compared to that with flaps retracted, will normally be:

choices.choice: Increase at moderate flap setting, decrease at large flap setting.
Smaller
Larger
Not change

subject: Performance

question: What is the effect of tail wind on the time to climb to a given altitude?

choices.choice: The time to climb increases
The time to climb decreases
The effect on time to climb will depend on the aeroplane type
The time to climb does not change

subject: Performance

question: Changing the take-off flap setting from flap 15° to flap 5° will normally result in:

choices.choice: a longer take-off distance and a better climb
a shorter take-off distance and an equal climb
a better climb and an equal take-off distance
a shorter take-off distance and a better climb

subject: Performance

question: What is the influence of the mass on maximum rate of climb (ROC. speed if all other parameters remain constant?

choices.choice: The ROC is affected by the mass, but not the ROC speed
The ROC and the ROC speed are independent of the mass
The ROC speed increases with increasing mass
The ROC speed decreases with increasing mass

subject: Performance

question: Following a take-off to the 50ft (15 m screen height, a light twin climbs on a gradient of 5%. It will clear a 160 m obstacle situated at 5,000 m from the 50 ft point with an obstacle clearance margin of:

choices.choice: it will not clear the obstacle

subject: Performance

question: The climb “gradient” is defined as the ratio of:

choices.choice: true airspeed to rate of climb
rate of climb to true airspeed
the increase of altitude to horizontal air distance expressed as a percentage
the horizontal air distance over the increase of altitude expressed as a percentage

subject: Performance

question: When flying an aircraft at: (i) Vx without flap (ii) Vx with flap (iii) Vy without flap (iv) Vy with flap. The aircraft should be achieving:

choices.choice: (i) The best rate of climb. (ii) The best rate of climb, but using a slightly faster speed than in (i) (iii) The best angle of climb (iv) The best angle of climb, but using a slightly faster speed than in (iii)
(i) A good angle of climb (ii) The best angle of climb (iii) A good rate of climb (iv) The best rate of climb

(i) The best angle of climb (ii) A slightly reduced angle of climb compared to i if using a slightly reduced speed than in i. (iii) The best rate of climb (iv) A slightly reduced rate of climb compared to iii if using a slightly reduced speed than in iii.
(i) A good rate of climb (ii) The best rate of climb (iii) A good angle of climb (iv) The best angle of climb

subject: Performance

question: Two identical aeroplanes at different masses are descending at idle thrust. Which of the following statements correctly describes their descent characteristics?

choices.choice: At a given angle of attack, both the vertical and the forward speed are greater for the heavier aeroplane.
There is no difference between the descent characteristics of the two aeroplanes.
At a given angle of attack the heavier aeroplane will always glide further than the lighter aeroplane.
At a given angle of attack the lighter aeroplane will always glide further than the heavier aeroplane.

subject: Performance

question: In a steady descending flight equilibrium of forces acting on the aeroplane is given by: (T=Thrust, D = Drag, W=Weight, descent angle = GAMMA)

choices.choice: T+D=-W sin GAMMA
T+W sin GAMMA = D
T - W sin GAMMA = D
T -D =W sin GAMMA

subject: Performance

question: Which of the following combinations has an effect on the angle of decent in a glide? (Ignore compressibility effects).

choices.choice: Configuration and mass.
Configuration and angle of attack.
Mass and altitude.
Altitude and configuration.

subject: Performance

question: Which statement is correct for a descent without engine thrust at maximum lift to drag ratio speed?

choices.choice: The mass of an aeroplane does not have any effect on the speed for descent
The higher the gross mass the greater is the speed for descent
The higher the gross mass the lower is the speed for descent.
The higher the average tempwrature (OAT, the lower is the speed for descent.

subject: Performance

question: An aeroplane is in a power off glide at best gliding speed. If the pilot increases pitch attitude the glide distance.

choices.choice: increases
remains the same
may increase or decrease depending on the aeroplane
decreases

subject: Performance

question: Is there any difference between the vertical speed versus forward speed curves for two identical aeroplanes having different masses? (assume zero thrust and wind)

choices.choice: Yes, the difference is that the lighter aeroplane will always glide a greater distance.
Yes, the difference is that for a given angle of attack both the vertical and forward speeds of the heavier aeroplane will be larger.
No difference.
Yes, the difference is that the heavier aeroplane will always glide a greater distance.

subject: Performance

question: Which statements is correct for a descent without engine thrust at maximum lift to drag ratio speed?

choices.choice: A tailwind component increases fuel and time to descent
A tailwind component decreases the ground distance.
A tailwind component increases the ground distance.
A headwind component increases the ground distance.

subject: Performance

question: An aeroplane executes a steady glide at the speed for minimum glide angle. If the forward speed is kept constant at VMD , what is the effect of a lower mass on the Rate of descent/ Glide angle/ CL/ CD ratio?

choices.choice: decreases/constant/decreases
increases/increases/constant
increases/constant/increases
decreases/constant/constant.

subject: Performance

question: Which of the following factors leads to the maximum flight time of a glide?

choices.choice: Low mass.
High mass.
Headwind.
Tailwind

subject: Performance

question: A constant headwind:

choices.choice: increases the descent distance over ground
increases the angle of the descent flight path.
increases the angle of descent
increases the rate of descent.

subject: Performance

question: An aeroplane carries out a descent maintaining at a constant Mach number in the first part of the descent and then at a constant indicated airspeed in the second part of the descent. How does the angle of descent change in the first and in the second part of the descent? Assume idle thrust and clean configuration and ignore compressibility effects.

choices.choice: Increases in the first part; is constant in the second.
Increases in the first part; decreases in the second.
Is constant in the first part; decrease in the second.
Decreases in the first part; increases in the second.

subject: Performance

question: During a glide at constant Mach number , the pitch angle of the aeroplane will:

choices.choice: decrease
increase
increase at first and decrease later on.
remain constant.

subject: Performance

question: Which of the following factors will lead to an increase of ground distance during a glide, while maintaining the appropriate minimum glide angle speed?

choices.choice: Headwind.
Tailwind.
Increase of aircraft mass.
Decrease of aircraft mass.

subject: Performance

question: A twin jet aeroplane is in cruise, with one engine inoperative, and has to overfly a high terrain area. In order to allow the greatest height clearance, the appropriate airspeed must be the airspeed:

choices.choice: giving the lowest Cd/Cl ratio.
for long-range cruise.
of greatest lift-to-drag ratio.
giving the lowest Cl/Cd ratio.

subject: Performance

question: What is the effect of increased mass on the performance of a gliding aeroplane at VMD?

choices.choice: The lift/drag ratio decreases
The speed for best angle descent increases.
There is no effect
The gliding angle decreases.

subject: Performance

question: A twin engined aeroplane in cruise flight with one engine inoperative has to fly over high ground. In order to maintain the highest possible altitude the pilot should choose’.

choices.choice: the speed corresponding to the minimum value of lift / drag ratio.
the speed at the maximum lift.
the speed corresponding to the maximum value of the lift / drag ratio
the long range speed.

subject: Performance

question: With all engines out, a pilot wants to fly for maximum time, Therefore he has to fly the speed corresponding to:

choices.choice: the minimum power required
the critical Mach number.
the minimum angle of descent.
the maximum lift

subject: Performance

question: Descending from cruising altitude to ground level at a constant IAS in a headwind, compared to still air conditions, will:

choices.choice: Reduce the time to descend.
Increase the time to descend
Reduce the ground distance taken
Reduce the fuel used in the descent.

subject: Performance

question: When descending at a constant Mach number:

choices.choice: The angle of attack remains constant.
The IAS decreases then increases.
The pitch angle will increase.
The pitch angle will decrease

subject: Performance

question: On a reciprocating engined aeroplane, with increasing altitude at constant gross mass, constant angle of attack and configuration, the power required:

choices.choice: remains unchanged but the TAS increases
increases and the TAS increases by the same percentage
increases but TAS remains constant
decreases slightly because of the lower air density

subject: Performance

question: Moving the centre of gravity from the forward to the aft limit: (gross mass, altitude and airspeed remain unchanged)

choices.choice: increases the power required
affects neither drag nor power required
increases the induced drag
decreases slightly because of the lower air density

subject: Performance

question: For jet-engined aeroplanes operating below the optimum altitude, what is the effect of increased altitude on specific range?

choices.choice: It does not change
Increases only if there is no wind
Increases
Decreases

subject: Performance

question: If the thrust available exceeds the thrust required for level flight:

choices.choice: the aeroplane accelerates if the altitude is maintained
the aeroplane descends if the airspeed is maintained
the aeroplane decelerates if it is in the region of reversed command
the aeroplane decelerates if the altitude is maintained

subject: Performance

question: Given a jet aircraft. Which order of speeds is correct?

choices.choice: Vs, Maximum range speed, Vx
Maximum endurance speed, Maximum range speed, VX
Vs, Vx Maximum range speed
Maximum endurance speed, Long range speed, Maximum range speed

subject: Performance

question: The pilot of a light twin engine aircraft has calculated a 4,000 m service ceiling with a take-off mass 3,250 kg, based on the general forecast conditions for the flight. If the take-off mass is 3,000 kg the service ceiling will be:

choices.choice: less than 4,000 m
unchanged, equal to 4,000 m
only a new performance analysis will determine if the service ceiling is higher or lower than 4,000 m
higher than 4,000 m

subject: Performance

question: Consider the graphic representation of the power required for a jet aeroplane versus true air speed (TAS). When drawing the tangent out of the origin, the point of contact determines the speed of:

choices.choice: critical angle of attack
maximum endurance
minimum power
maximum specific range

subject: Performance

question: In the drag versus speed curve for a jet aeroplane, the speed for maximum range corresponds with:

choices.choice: the point of contact of the tangent from the origin to the drag curve
the point of intersection of the parasite drag curve and the induced drag curve
the point of contact of the tangent from the origin to the parasite drag curve
the point of contact of the tangent from the origin to the induced drag curve

subject: Performance

question: The speed VS is defined as the:

choices.choice: speed for best specific range
stalling speed or minimum steady flight speed at which the aeroplane is controllable
safety speed for take-off in case of a contaminated runway
design stress speed

subject: Performance

question: What is the effect of a head wind component, compared to still air, on the maximum range speed for maximum climb angle respectively?

choices.choice: Maximum range speed decreases and maximum climb angle speed decreases
Maximum range speed increases and maximum climb angle speed increases
Maximum range speed increases and maximum climb angle speed stays constant
maximum range speed decreases and maximum climb angle speed increases

subject: Performance

question: A jet aeroplane is flying at the long range cruise speed at the optimum altitude. How does the specific range / fuel flow change over a given time period?

choices.choice: Decrease / decrease
Increase / decrease
Increase / increase
Decrease / increase

subject: Performance

question: The maximum indicated air speed of a piston engined aeroplane, in level flight, is reached:

choices.choice: at the service ceiling
at the practical ceiling
at the lowest possible altitude
at the optimum cruise altitude

subject: Performance

question: The optimum cruise altitude increases:

choices.choice: if the aeroplane mass is decreased
if the temperature (OAT) is increased
if the tailwind component is decreased
if the aeroplane mass is increased

subject: Performance

question: What affect has a tailwind on the maximum endurance speed?

choices.choice: No affect
Tailwind only affects holding speed
The IAS will be increased
The IAS will be decreased

subject: Performance

question: Which of the equations below defines specific air range (SR)?

choices.choice: SR=Groundspeed / Total Fuel Flow
SR=True Airspeed / Total Fuel Flow
SR=Indicated Airspeed / Total Fuel Flow
SR=Mach Number / Total Fuel Flow

subject: Performance

question: Which of the following statements, with regard to the optimum altitude (best fuel mileage), is correct?

choices.choice: An aeroplane usually flies above the optimum cruise altitude, as this provides the largest specific range
An aeroplane sometimes flies above the optimum cruise altitude, because ATC normally does not allow to fly continuously at the optimum cruise altitude.
An aeroplane always flies below the optimum cruise altitude, as otherwise Mach buffet can occur
An aeroplane always flies on the optimum cruise altitude, because this is most attractive from an economy point of view

subject: Performance

question: The optimum altitude:

choices.choice: is the altitude up to which cabin pressure of 8 000 ft can be maintained
increases as mass decreases and is the altitude at which the specific range reaches its maximum
decreases as mass decreases
is the altitude at which the specific range reaches its minimum

subject: Performance

question: A lower airspeed at constant mass and altitude requires:

choices.choice: less thrust and a lower coefficient of lift
more thrust and a lower coefficient of lift
more thrust and a lower coefficient of drag
a higher coefficient of lift

subject: Performance

question: The point at which a tangent out of the origin touches the power required curve:

choices.choice: is the point where Drag coefficient is a minimum
is the point where the Lift of Drag ratio is a minimum
is the maximum drag speed
is the point where the Lift to Drag ratio is a maximum

subject: Performance

question: The long range cruise speed (LRC) is in relation to the speed for maximum range cruise (MRC)?

choices.choice: Lower
Depending on the OAT and net mass
Depending on density altitude and mass
Higher

subject: Performance

question: The maximum horizontal speed occurs when:

choices.choice: The thrust is equal to minimum drag
The thrust does not increase further with increasing speed
The maximum thrust is equal to the total drag
The thrust is equal to the maximum drag

subject: Performance

question: Under which condition should you fly considerably lower (4,000 ft or more) than the optimum altitude?

choices.choice: If at the lower altitude either more headwind or less tailwind can be expected
If at the lower altitude either considerably less headwind or considerably more tailwind can be expected
If the maximum altitude is below the optimum altitude
If the temperature is lower at the low altitude (high altitude inversion.

subject: Performance

question: The optimum cruise altitude is:

choices.choice: the pressure altitude up to which a cabin altitude of 8,000 ft can be maintained
the pressure altitude at which the TAS for high speed buffet is a maximum
the pressure altitude at which the best specific range can be achieved
the pressure altitude at which the fuel flow is a maximum

subject: Performance

question: Maximum endurance for a prison engined aeroplane is achieved at:

choices.choice: The speed that approximately corresponds to the maximum rate of climb speed
The speed for maximum lift coefficient
The speed for minimum drag
The speed that corresponds to the speed for maximum climb angle

subject: Performance

question: On a long distance flight the gross mass decreases continuously as a consequence of the fuel consumption. The result is:

choices.choice: The speed must be increased to compensate the lower mass
The specific range increases and the optimum altitude decreases
The specific range decreases and the optimum altitude increases
The specific range and the optimum altitude increases

subject: Performance

question: A jet aeroplane is climbing at constant Mach number below the tropopause. Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.choice: IAS decreases and TAS decreases
IAS increases and TAS increases
IAS decreases and TAS increases
IAS increases and TAS decreases

subject: Performance

question: Why are ‘step climbs’ used on long distance flights?

choices.choice: Step climbs do not have any special purpose for jet aeroplanes; they are used for piston engine aeroplanes only
ATC do not permit cruise climbs
To fly as close as possible to the optimum altitude as aeroplane mass reduces
Step climbs are only justified if at the higher altitude less headwind or more tailwind can be expected

subject: Performance

question: Which of the following sequences of speed for a jet aeroplane is correct? (from low to high speeds.

choices.choice: Maximum endurance speed, maximum range speed, maximum angle of climb speed
Maximum endurance speed, long range speed, maximum range speed
Vs, maximum angle climb speed, maximum range speed
Vs, maximum range speed, maximum angle climb speed

subject: Performance

question: The pilot of a jet aeroplane wants to use a minimum amount of fuel between two airfields. Which flight procedure should the pilot fly?

choices.choice: Maximum endurance
Holding
Long range
Maximum range

subject: Performance

question: Long range cruise is selected as:

choices.choice: the higher speed to achieve 99% of maximum specific range in zero wind
the speed for best economy (ECON)
the climbing cruise with one or two engines inoperative
specific range with tailwind

subject: Performance

question: The optimum long-range cruise altitude for a turbo-jet aeroplane:

choices.choice: is only dependent on the outside air temperature
increases when the aeroplane mass decreases
is always equal to the powerplant ceiling
is independent of the aeroplane mass

subject: Performance

question: Maximum endurance:

choices.choice: is the same as maximum specific range with wind correction
can be flown in a steady climb only
can be reached with the 'best rate of climb' speed in level flight
is achieved in unaccelerated level flight with minimum fuel consumption

subject: Performance

question: For a piston engined aeroplane, the speed for maximum range is:

choices.choice: that which gives the maximum lift to drag ratio
that which gives the minimum value of power
that which gives the maximum value of lift
1.4 times the stall speed in clean configuration

subject: Performance

question: The speed for maximum endurance:

choices.choice: is always higher than the speed for maximum specific range
is always lower than the speed for maximum specific range
is the lower speed to achieve 99% of maximum specific range
can either be higher or lower than the speed for maximum specific range

subject: Performance

question: The intersections of the thrust available and the drag curve are the operating points of the aeroplane:

choices.choice: in un-accelerated climb
in un-accelerated level flight
in descent with constant IAS
in accelerated level flight

subject: Performance

question: For a jet transport aeroplane,which of the following is the reason for the use of ‘maximum range speed’?

choices.choice: Minimises specific fuel consumption
Minimises fuel flow
Longest flight duration
Minimises drag

subject: Performance

question: The centre of gravity moving near to, but still within, the aft limit;

choices.choice: increases the stalling speed
improves the longitudinal stability
decreases the maximum range
improves the maximum range

subject: Performance

question: A jet aeroplane is performing a maximum range flight. The speed corresponds to:

choices.choice: the minimum drag
the minimum required power
the point of contact of the tangent from the origin to the power required (Pr. versus TAS curve
the point of contact of the tangent from the origin to the Drag versus TAS curve

subject: Performance

question: During a cruise flight of a jet aeroplane at a constant flight level and at the maximum range speed, the IAS / the drag will:

choices.choice: increase / increase
decrease / increase
decrease / decrease
increase / decrease

subject: Performance

question: Which of the following is a reason to operate an aeroplane at ‘long range speed’?

choices.choice: The aircraft can be operated close to the buffet onset speed
In order to prevent loss of speed stability and tuck-under
It offers greatly reduced time costs than with maximum range speed
In order to achieve speed stability

subject: Performance

question: Long range cruise is a flight procedure which gives:

choices.choice: an IAS which is 1% higher than the IAS for maximum specific range
a specific range which is 99% of maximum specific range and a lower cruise speed
a specific range which is about 99% of maximum specific range and higher cruise speed
a 1% higher TAS for maximum specific range

subject: Performance

question: The lowest point of the frag or thrust required curve of a jet aeroplane, is the point for:

choices.choice: minimum drag and maximum endurance
maximum specific range and minimum power
minimum power
minimum specific range

subject: Performance

question: If other factors are unchanged, the fuel mileage or range (nautical miles per kg. is :

choices.choice: independent from the centre of gravity position
lower with an aft centre of gravity position
higher with a forward centre of gravity position
lower with a forward centre of gravity position

subject: Performance

question: To achieve the maximum range over ground with headwind the airspeed should be:

choices.choice: lower compared to the speed for maximum range cruise with no wind
reduced to the gust penetration speed
higher compared to the speed for maximum range cruise with no wind
equal to the speed for maximum range cruise with no wind

subject: Performance

question: When utilising the step climb technique, one should wait for the weight reduction, from fuel burn, to result in:

choices.choice: The aerodynamic ceiling to increase by approximately 2,000ft above the present altitude whereby one would climb approximately 4,000ft higher
The optimum altitude to increase by approximately 2,000ft above the present altitude, whereby one would climb approximately 4,000ft higher
The manoeuvre ceiling to increase by approximately 2,000ft above the present altitude, whereby one would climb approximately 4,000ft higher
The en-route ceiling to increase by approximately 2,000ft above the present altitude, whereby one would climb approximately 4,000ft higher

subject: Performance

question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the performance of an aeroplane in level flight?

choices.choice: The maximum level flight speed will be obtained when the power required equals the maximum power available from the engine
The minimum level flight speed will be obtained when the power required equals the maximum power available from the engine
The maximum level flight speed will be obtained when the power required equals the minimum power available from the engine
The maximum level flight speed will be obtained when the power required equals the power available from the engine

subject: Performance

question: The landing reference speed V ref has, in accordance with international requirements, the following margins above the stall speed in landing configuration for a Class B aeroplane:
subject: Performance

question: At a given mass, the stalling speed of a twin engine, class B aeroplane is 100kt in the landing configuration. The minimum speed a pilot must maintain in short final is:

choices.choice: 130 kt
115 kt
125 kt
120 kt

subject: Performance

question: The stalling speed or the minimum steady flight speed at which the aeroplane is controllable in landing configuration is abbreviated as:

choices.choice: VS1
VS
VMC
VSO

subject: Performance

question: What margin above the stall speed is provided by the landing reference V ref for a Class B aeroplane?

choices.choice: 1.10 VSO
VMCA x 1.2
1.30 VSO
1.05 VSO

subject: Performance

question: An increase in atmospheric pressure has, among other things, the following consequences on landing performance:

choices.choice: a reduced landing distance and degraded go around performance
a reduced landing distance and improved go-around performance
an increased landing distance and degraded go-around performance
an increased landing distance and improved go-around performance

subject: Performance

question: The take-off distance of an aircraft is 600 m in a standard atmosphere, with no wind and at a pressure altitude of 0 ft. Using the following corrections: ± 20m / 1,000 ft field elevation, – 5m /kt headwind, ± 15m / % runway slope, ± 5m /°C deviation from standard temperature. The take-off distance from an airport at 1,000 ft elevation, temperature 17°C, QNH 1013.25 hPa, 1% up-slope, 10 kt tailwind is?
subject: Performance

question: To minimize the risk of hydroplaning during the landing the pilot of a modern airliner should:

choices.choice: make a "positive" landing and apply maximum reverse thrust and brakes as quickly as possible
use maximum reverse thrust, and should start braking below the hydroplaning speed
use normal landing, braking and reverse thrust techniques
postpone the landing until the risk of hydroplaning no longer exists

subject: Performance

question: An aircraft has two certified landing flaps positions 25° and 35°. If a pilot chooses 25° instead of 35°, the aircraft will have:

choices.choice: a reduced landing distance and better go-around performance
an increased landing distance and degraded go-around performance
a reduced landing distance and degraded go-around performance
an increased landing distance and better go-around performance

subject: Performance

question: May anti-skid be considered to determine the take-off and landing data?

choices.choice: Only for take-off
Only for landing
Yes
No

subject: Performance

question: An aircraft has two certified landing flaps positions, 25° and 35°. If a pilot chooses 35° instead of 25°, the aircraft will have:

choices.choice: an increased landing distance and better go-around performance
a reduced landing distance and degraded go-around performance
a reduced landing distance and better go-around performance
an increased landing distance and degraded go-around performance

subject: Performance

question: For a single engine Class B aeroplane, how does runway slope affect allowable take-off mass, assuming other factors remain constant and not limiting?

choices.choice: An uphill slope decreases take-off mass.
Allowable take-off mass is not affected by runway slope
A downhill slope decreases allowable take-off mass
A downhill slope increases allowable take-off mass

subject: Performance

question: For this question use Performance Manual CAP 698 SEP 1 Figure 2.1. With regard to the take-off performance chart for the single engine aeroplane, determine the take-off speed for (1) rotation and (2) at a height of 50ft. choices.choice: 73 and 84 kt
68 and 78 kt
65 and 75 kt
71 and 82 kt

subject: Performance

question: For this question use Performance Manual CAP 698 SEP 1 Figure 2.2. subject: Performance

question: For this question use Performance Manual CAP 698 SEP 1 Figure 2.1. With regard to the take off performance chart for the single engine aeroplane determine the maximum allowable take off mass. Given:- O.A.T : ISA, Pressure Altitude : 4,000ft, Headwind component : 5kt, Flaps : up, Runway : Tarred and Dry, Factored runway length : 2,000ft, Obstacle height : 50ft
subject: Performance

choices.choice: approximately: 2,200 feet
approximately: 2,400 feet
approximately: 1,400 feet
approximately: 2,800 feet

question: For this question use Performance Manual CAP 698 SEP 1 Figure 2.2. With regard to the take-off performance chart for the single engine aeroplane determine the take-off distance to a height of 50ft. choices.choice: approximately: 1,150 ft
approximately: 2,450 ft
approximately: 1,500 ft
approximately: 2,100 ft

question: For this question use Performance Manual CAP 698 SEP 1 Figure 2.1. With regard to the take-off performance chart for the single engine aeroplane determine the take-off distance to a height of 50ft. Given:- Airport characteristics: hard, dry and zero slope runway, Pressure altitude: 1,500ft, Outside air temperature: +18°C, wind component: 4 knots tailwind, Take-off mass: 1,270 kg.
subject: Performance

question: For this question use Performance Manual CAP 698 SEP 1 Figure 2.2. With regard to the take-off performance chart for the single engine aeroplane determine the take-off distance to a height of 50 ft. Given:- O.A.T: 38°C, Pressure Altitude: 4,000 ft, Aeroplane Mass: 3,400 Ibs, Tailwind component: 5 kt, Flaps: Approach setting, Runway: Dry Grass, Correction factor: 1.2

choices.choice: approximately: 3,250 ft
approximately: 4,200 ft
approximately: 5,040 ft
approximately: 3,900 ft

subject: Performance

question: For a Class B aircraft at an aerodrome with no stopway or clearway, the minimum length of Take-off Run that must be available to satisfy the take-off requirements:

choices.choice: Must not be less than the gross take off distance to 50ft.
Must not be less than 1.15 times the gross take off distance to 50ft.
Must not be less than 1.25 times the gross take off distance to 50ft.
Must not be less than 1.3 times the gross take off distance to 50ft

subject: Performance

question: For a single engine Class B aircraft, the rotation speed VR:

choices.choice: Must not be less than 1.1 VS1
Must not be less than VS1
Must not be less than 1.2 VMC
Must not be less than VMC

subject: Performance

question: For a single engine Class B aircraft at an aerodrome with stopway:

choices.choice: The TOD x 1.3 must not exceed the ASDA.
The TOD must not exceed the ASDA x 1.3.
The TOD x 1.25 must not exceed the ASDA.
